dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA swoops along a shimmering black sand beach, mounta rising in the further distance... FINDING: in the middle distance: EIGHT WARRIORS galloping HORSEBACK, armed with spears, swords, shields, netting, torches. DOGS race along at their sides. At the head of the troop rides a grizzled mid-aged WARRIO grimly determined, his face obscured by his battle mask. The warriors race on, riding to beat the devil home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the sun gone below a ridge of barren hills, the dark is quickly retaking the ground, bleeding out from the crevices of rock, the moss, a stream twisting through the emerald meadow... ++.in the middle distance of which GOATS and SHEEP amble about. Beyond them, rocky outcrops give way to a dark and shifti sea... and the low RUMBLE of surf... Into the foreground there slowly shifts: a huge, stooped FIGURE. Erect, he'd be nearly seven feet tall, and is twi the mass of an average man, covered in hair - much of it greying. Immense arms lead to massive hands, the tough na tools for a brutal existence. His face - or what can be made of it in the falling light has a leatherish quality. It also betrays age, as does a noticeable limp: this is a gigantic nocturnal primate - a troll who has seen better days. He scans the meadow, puzzled. He CLUCKS his tongue a coup of times... GRUNTS out a name of some sort...

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Grrruhnellll.... He twists his head to one side, raises his nose and sniff the wind... wary for a moment... then the moment passes.. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 2.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He shuffles forward a few more steps, still searching, wo now edging in. He CLUCKS his tongue again -- --.and he's slammed from behind by something -- В»-.or, as it turns out, someone: his small child - GREND who promptly tumbles past his father, CACKLING at the pra From the distance comes the sound of a DOG BARKING. The father snatches at Grendel. He misses, tries again, a it becomes a little chase. Finally the father scoops up Grendel and berates him in w several low guttural words - a primitive tongue with echo of Old Norse. Grendel responds by grabbing his father's nose and twisti it, laughing. The father then laughs too. But once again the father grows wary. Holding Grendel clo he sniffs the air. More BARKING DOGS.... ...then the far-off SHOUTS of HUMANS. The father urgently swings Grendel up onto his shoulder, fear overcoming his infirmity - with great strides he cro back out of the meadow toward the rock outcrops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The troop of warriors race along... +-+-till the lead warrior pulls up, eyeing the rocks to e side. He sniffs the breeze, considers... .--the others waiting on his judgement... ..-then he abruptly jerks his horse toward a break in the rocks, leading up into a meadow... ...the other warriors following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grendel's father is moving as best he can... but one hip giving him trouble, and his wind is quickly going on him. Grendel stares back over his shoulder, his face now betra the same fear his father feels. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 3.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They scramble over rock, twist along moss paths, then dow into a stream... then up the bank, up past massive boulders... the sound of the DOGS and HORSES edging ever closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two trolls emerge into view of the sea. Grendel's fat rushes up to the cliff edge, and verbally/gesturally dire Grendel to descend. Grendel starts down a few feet before turning and meeting father's fierce gaze. He gestures to Grendel to continue down. Grendel does, but steals a glance back up to find.. ..-his father turning to meet their pursuers. Grendel cli back up to the cliffs' edge to see... ...the warriors charging in on horseback. Several dismoun and take positions on the periphery. The lead warrior continues forward. Now we see he's significantly older than the rest; there are years of the sort of battles in him. And yet the fire is still in his - even as it meets the troll's. The other warriors hold back, waiting on their leader's m The troll scowls back, a snarl escaping. The lead warrior, unfazed, even spurred on by the challen charges forward and flings a leather bag at Grendel's fat The bag - hitting - bursts apart, throwing liquid pitch o him. As other warriors rush forward with torches... ...Grendel twists back down into the rocks, terrified. There come the SOUNDS of a vicious FIGHT above.... the RO of his father... the warriors' SHOUTS and the BARKING/WAI of dogs... the NEIGHING, HUFFING and STOMPING of the horses... A dog flies past, over the cliff to the rocks below... Then a sudden WHOOSH... a terrifying SCREECH... ...and Grendel's father staggers off the cliff, stuck wit spears, wrapped in netting, and engulfed in FLAMES. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 4.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: His body twists down, and SLAPS onto the rocks below, whe it lies motionless, burning... until the first wave washe in, extinguishing the flames. Grendel gasps as... ...-TORCHES drop through the air on either side, continui down to the rocks below - the warriors seeking confirmati of the kill. Their CHEERS of celebration wash down over Grendel, and h looks up to see... ...the lead warrior peering down into the dark, a spear raised ready to throw, his figure silhouetted against the torch-lights. What Grendel does not see... .--is the warrior nudge up his battle-mask... REVEALING: the wild battle-eyes of the Danish king - HROT [50]. His ferocious gaze softens, turns to pugzlement. Hrothgar, squinting, makes out... В«--the tiny troll figure of Grendel nestled in the rocks Hrothgar is clearly torn. He gulps in a breath. His hand tightens in grip on his spear, his mind racing. Grendel buries his face in his arms. Finally, Hrothgar's puzzlement shifts to decision. He wip the troll-blood from his eyes. Pity overtakes him. His spear-arm drops... and he turns away. Grendel, burrowed into the rocks, steals a glance up to find... ..-the warrior gone from the cliffside, the sounds of the hunt-party diminishing. But the sound is replaced by Grendel's own sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grendel comes warily down the stony beach, gaze sweeping about in search, hands dragging an old sword. Finally his gaze falls on what he's been searching for... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 5.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ...the CORPSE of his father washed up in the rocks. He fights back sobs, and struggles to dislodge it... but the corpse is too heavy. He resolves himself, then raises the sword, and swings it down repeatedly onto the corpse's neck. Exhausted and crying, he takes up the severed head - a gr weight for him - and cradles it in his small arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON: the desiccated HEAD of Grendel's father, positioned i erude alcove-shrine, on either side of which small smudge burn... The fires have somewhat preserved the head: the eye socke are empty, and the flesh is gone from the face, but the s has dried and tightened, the long wild hair remains, matt over and beyond the great brow, the yellow teeth clenched eternal grin/grimace... Sea-shells, stones, and dried flowers are placed around t head. REVEAL: Grendel, now an adult, squatting down near a larg fire-bed of embers, gaze fixed on his father's head... hi own thoughts clearly melancholic... A breath rolls through him like a shudder. He rises... ..-revealing his stature: he's huge, with powerful limbs, scale of his father but with none of the infirmity. He starts up a rocky path toward the faint light of the cave entrance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grendel emerges out onto the cliff edge, and stares down the crashing water on the rocks below... +--menace rising in his glassy-gaze, he squats down... ...snatches up a fist-sized rock and smashes himself once the forehead... Blood streams down from his brow and across his face. He licks the blood as it reaches his lip. Grunts a bitter SIGH/LAUGH at his wretched state. Blinks through the bloo at... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 6.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ...the sun edging down into the sea. He wipes the blood over his cheeks, chin, brow - a battle mask in the making.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the light fading from the sky... ...the sounds of a CELEBRATION... LAUGHTER, MUSIC... drif from the village... * A CROWD of VILLAGERS circle about... * В«+-SNORRI [60s] who lifts a blood-stained pine-branch fr the opened chest of a slaughtered ram lying on a rock. * Hrothgar [60s now] goes down on one knee before him. Thou greying, he wears his added years as well as any warrior- could. Snorri touches Hrothgar's forehead with the blood. *

dialogues.speaker: SNORRI
dialogues.text: Hrothgar, much-loved King of the Danes, under Odin's eye I blood you lucky on all paths that leave this hall. A CHEER from the crowd. Hrothgar rises, smiling, and turns to his grand hall. His radiant wife - WEALHTHEOW [40s] - hands him a clay ju Hrothgar pulls the cap from it with his teeth and pours w out across the steps. As it splashes down...

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: May all those who cross these steps find a happy heart! More CHEERS rise up from the villagers... Hrothgar draws his sword and smashes the jug, sealing the blessing... .В»..and as the villagers line up to be - in turn - "bloo by Snorri, Snorri bursting out in resonant SONG... * (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 7.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: REVEAL THE LS POV: as that of Grendel, rising over a rock the foreground. His expression is solemn. He sniffs the a deeply. A shudder runs through him at the sound of the song... th rising of a mission in his gaze and in his blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With some RAUCOUS drunken ROARS and HOWLS echoing through village... and - at some distance - REVELLERS making thei swerving way back to the longhouse... .-.-a lone torch-lit GUARD moves along a boulder ridge, s in hand, grinning at the drunks. But then an ANIMAL HOWL rises rom the darkness beyond, to which he turns...

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Come near here, y'shitbrain wolves, you'll get a mouth of spear. There's movement in the stones below, just beyond the boulders, just out of sight. The guard peers over. Nothing for several beats... but then a strange BREATH-LI sound on the wind...

dialogues.speaker: GRENDEL
dialogues.text: Speee-arrrr... The guard takes the torch from the holder in the stone, h it out into the darkness, trying to figure what's below. Several small stones hit him in the face, and he jerks ba in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: (wary mutter) What the... The guard throws the torch down into the darkness. Something large deftly shifts out of sight to one side. There's a scratching of nail on stone as something climbs the boulder.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Olaf?! Pal?! The guard swings his spear toward the sound, but without torch he can't see much. Then, again, there's silence. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 11 12 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 8.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The guard moves to the edge, his spear high, ready to sta -.. but from the side a large dark LIMB swings out, the h slapping the guard in the face. The thin CRACK of bone snapping. The guard drops, shudders briefly, then his body goes sti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIGHT bleeds in with the CREAKY opening of the huge door,

dialogues.speaker: REVEALING
dialogues.text: ...the night's carnage: broken benches, the BODIES of sev slain warriors... blood splashed about... ANGLE BACK ON: Hrothgar standing, stunned, in the doorway with UNFERTH [30], a sturdy and well-scarred Danish warri to one side and AESCHERE [late 60s], Hrothgar's peer, to other. Hrothgar, with Aeschere at this side, determinedly edges forward over the slippery wood... ....Unferth - hungover and bloodstained - an awkward step behind.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: Where were you when all this --

dialogues.speaker: UNFERTH
dialogues.text: (awkward) Asleep. I'd... I'd... had some beers.

dialogues.speaker: AESCHERE
dialogues.text: No others saw what happened?

dialogues.speaker: UNFERTH
dialogues.text: None who can speak.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: (through his teeth) What fucking thing would dare -- But his words end, and his steps slow. Hrothgar, stunned, crosses the floor past the dead fire-p to a slumped FIGURE on the throne at the far end of the r (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12 13 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 9.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: It's the guard from the wall, one hand clutching his spea in readiness... his hood hanging over his face. Hrothgar edges up, takes up a spear and, with its point, lifts the guard's hood - gasps - and jerks back. Rolling off the shoulders - where his head should be - is bloody head-sized stone. It hits the floor with a great THUMP, and rolls across it, coming to a stop at Hrothgar' feet. ON: Hrothgar's face, his horror giving way to a grim realization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA slowly sweeps over sea-water... coming to rest... ON: BEOWULF [30]... or at least his head, seeming to eeri bob on a plank of wood on the surface of the water. The odd wave splashes over him... his eyes closed, face betraying no life... then suddenly a long SIGH of exhaust and relief... His eyes flicker open, he blinks, and slowly edges in tow land, his neck, shoulders, torso inch-by-inch revealed... ..-watched by a lone FISHERMAN on the beach mending his n Beowulf, delirious, pushes aside the wooden plank, limps onto the sand, trailing seaweed, his shins and thighs burdened by lamprey EELS attached to his flesh... He wears a battle-weathered leather tunic, shredded tweed pants, a baldric-strap tying his sheathed sword to his back... His body, though battered and scarred, is obviously one o great power. His wobbly-kneed stagger still manages the grace of the warrior/athlete returning from a struggle wh nearly killed him.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: G'day. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 10.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: G'day. I'd owe much to know my whereabouts.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: Fish Beach... but likely I'm the only one who names it that. (off Beowulf's look / wry) Where I get fish. The fisherman goes to his fire-pit and takes from it a smoking stick.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: I mean who's your king? The fisherman looks back across the land, considers it...

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: Well... y'know how these things go. As he talks, he indicates various directions and movement with his stick...

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Late as a couple years ago I think it was a Hathobard. Swedes rolled in, pushed them out... Hathobards came back, pushed them out - then they got pushed out by Geats. Wulfings showed up... (beat / sighs) Sig Skullsplitter of the Hathobards was spilling blood this way last spring. But then he got sick from sleeping with the sheep. Swedes came back...

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: (hint of worry) It's Swedish land then?

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: I wouldn't bet a fish on that. Hygelac the Geat then lay a beating on the Swedes... (beat) I had a boatload of Wulfings wash up. But they were just corpses. Stunk to Valhalla. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 11.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Had to let'm dry out a week then I put the whole little crowd to flame - not knowin what they died of, eh. (beat / shrugs) Yeah, I'll be guessing this is Geat land for now. Beowulf's relief is apparent.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sleep with that, canya?

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Being a Geat... (nods) I'm Beowulf. * By Beowulf's look, it's clear he expects his name to * register, but - just as clearly - it doesn't. *

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: Beowulf... what, the Eel Meal? The fisherman nods to Beowulf's eel-infested shins. Beowu looks down, gets dizzy and drops to the sand where he sit

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: You've not had another wash up...? Like myself... name of Breca? The fisherman shakes his head. As Beowulf talks, the fisherman methodically starts poking and singeing the eel with the stick: they unclasp from Beowulf's bloodied fles and drop to the sand, where they squirm till the fisherma whacks them dead.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We were out hunting whale the other day. Storm came up and ate our boat. Breca bet he could beat me to shore. I lost sight of him in the swells. The fisherman tries to fathom this.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: So this is just you coming in now? Beowulf nods. The fisherman gives a dubious look.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Y'ever swum in the open sea? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 14 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 12.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: Leave that to my boat. Beowulf stares a beat at the fisherman.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Am I right to think you mock me? 13 The fisherman considers Beowulf's grim manner, and his sw He starts to gather the eels and throw them in a pot.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: Can't see much life in that. (beat) You do this a lot?

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: I take what comes.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: Good. Then you'll have no qualms if supper tastes like you. Beowulf stares. The fisherman gives a battered-tooth grin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 The fisherman pokes at his fire while Beowulf nibbles at plate of the cooked eels.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: So... what's it like being a hero? Quelling things with axes and that sword of yours... in - what - a kinda bloody madness? Beowulf chafes slightly.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: In truth I don't get all that mad.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: That's all I've heard of your sort.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: You should hear what they say about fishermen. They trade a wry grin. The fisherman stirs the fire.. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 15 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 13.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: So... a hero, eh? A hero for supper. Don't my shit shine! The fisherman notices Beowulf's squeamishness with the ee

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: (eyeing Beowulf's plate) Eat up. Be yourself! And the fisherman cackles at his joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beowulf and the fisherman stand before a rack of dried fi The fisherman is packing some in a small pouch, which he hands to Beowulf. Beowulf claps him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: I'm in your debt.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I'm in the fishes'. (grim / to the water) One o' these days they'll come for theirs.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Good luck. May Aegir keep you from hunger.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: Good luck with your killing things. I guess you thank - who - Thor?

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: That's uh... not all I do --

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: No, I'm sure y'piss and shit just like the rest of us. Gotta say there's not much use for that here. (off his look) Hitting things with axes. Y'oughta try Daneland.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Daneland. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 16 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 14.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, word from the whale-road they got one unhappy troll on the loose there.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: (dismissive) I'd think the Danes could handle a troll.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: Guess the first eighty thought so too.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: (jolted) Eighty?!

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: Well... y'know how these things go. Some say twenty, some say two hundred.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Two hundred?!

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah it bent my brain too... thinking that many Danes could even hold a sword.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: (sharp) I know the Danes. They've bloodied seas. The fisherman reads the ferocity of Beowulf's emotion.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: Eh, I'm just a fisherman. Beowulf looks out over the water, torn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beowulf strides along a sheep trail, crosses over a ridge find... ---a smoldering ruin of a HUT, a few SHEEP about. FIVE ro looking MEN are eating at a fire-pit. He edges forward, eyeing the smoke. They eye him warily. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 15.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST MAN
dialogues.text: Dragon came in the night.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: (playing surprise) Dragon.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST MAN
dialogues.text: Never heard of dragons?

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Oh, I've heard. Just always thought they were tales. (glancing around) And it left without the sheep. (off their looks) Just seems odd... from what I've heard of dragons... to leave a sheep. They offer shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So who are your people? (off their looks) I know most Geats. And this being Geat land --

dialogues.speaker: FIRST MAN
dialogues.text: What's it to you? Beowulf then spots some movement further back behind a woodpile. His hand slides to the hilt of his sword. The first man fixes on the magnificent hilt - a sword of renown. He eyes Beowulf with more concern.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's some sword. You have a name?

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: I don't know yours, you likely won't know mine. Beowulf. The others react - looks shooting amongst them - a name t know and fear. Furtively they reach for their own weapons. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 16.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe your dragon came back. And Beowulf edges up the slope toward the shed... ...till he spots a MAN on the ground humping something. As Beowulf nears, he makes out... ...the limp arm of a woman, extended over the rock and on jerking with the thrust of the man. The scenario becomes immediately clear to him: the burned hut, the dead woman. He draws his sword, and directly advances on the bandit group... ...all of whom now brandish weapons - though defensively. The first man stumbles back, his movement putting the lie his words.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST MAN
dialogues.text: Go now, you can go with your life.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: This is my life. (ironic mutter) A bloody madness. And he charges forward, swinging his blade... immediately slashing the first man to the ground. A second man comes and, after a couple of traded sword- strokes, Beowulf grabs the other's sword-arm, and then cu him down too. A third man comes at Beowulf, who blocks his sword-swing, grabs the wretch by the throat, and crushes it in his han The last two from the fire-pit group now have clearly panicked expressions. Nonetheless, they come at him with their swords. Beowulf routinely meets their strokes, then snatches hold one, throws him into the other, then decapitates both ina stroke. The headless clutching corpses then shudder to the ground Beowulf turns and marches up the slope. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 17 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 17.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The necrophile, having just secured his pants, starts scrambling up the slope, WHINING fear. Beowulf follows for a few beats - and gaining ground - th heaves his sword into the air. It sails some distance before descending and catching the necrophile in his leg. He tumbles to the ground, SCREAMIN Beowulf strides up to him, pulls his sword from the leg..

dialogues.speaker: NECROPHILE
dialogues.text: (a plea) She was dead!

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Yeah. She was. And Beowulf swings his blade down upon the wretch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beowulf places the dead woman - wrapped, with care, in a blanket - into a shallow grave. Blood is splattered over his face and clothes, but the wildness has left his eyes: now he looks only weary. The CRACK of a branch behind him, and Beowulf twists abou ready to fight... .--but finds a CHILD [6-7], face tear-streaked, fear in h eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CHILD
dialogues.text: Are you a dragon queller? Beowulf considers, shrugs...

dialogues.speaker: CHILD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You quell children? Beowulf shakes his head. The child eyes his mother.

dialogues.speaker: CHILD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She might be scared here with these men.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Don't worry. Crows'll come for them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 18 19 20 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 18.

dialogues.speaker: CHILD
dialogues.text: Then she'll be alone. *

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: The gods'll watch over. *

dialogues.speaker: CHILD
dialogues.text: They didn't before. * Beowulf can't argue. He continues gently covering the bod the child approaching and helping to pat down the earth o the grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beowulf comes up over a ridge on foot, leading a HORSE, o which the child sleeps. Beowulf smiles, his gaze finding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +-+-.a group of tents and SEVERAL DOZEN GEATS, cooking fi sending smoke to the skies, MUSIC and LAUGHTER drifting u the hills. It's an annual gathering place - large standing stones se a great circle, and... В»-.-.across a black beach to the water, A COUPLE of LONG lie at anchor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a LONGSHIP silhouetted in the background... ---Beowulf sits almost central at a firepit - opposite hi king - HYGELAC [50s] - surrounded by a cluster of Geat warriors... ...the great standing stones looming over them like guardians, the firelight already throwing wild shadows... Among the Geat warriors is BRECA [30], almost as sturdy a Beowulf...and, beside him, HONDSCIOH [late 20s], Beowulf' best friend, and sitting to Beowulf's right. In Beowulf's lap, the exhausted child is curled asleep in spite - or because - of the raucous warrior band. All of them have been - and are still - drinking, and eat A short distance away, a group of Geat WOMEN are LAUGHING and TALKING among themselves. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 19.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: THORKEL [30], the Geat poet, stands before the men with h harp, playing a powerful melody. His manner is serious, s absorbed, ignoring the questionable attention of some of others. His voice rises, resonant, hypnotic...

dialogues.speaker: THORKEL
dialogues.text: In a game to gut boredom Great Beowulf and Breca... Hondscioh rolls his eyes, snorts derision. Beowulf smiles him.

dialogues.speaker: THORKEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-hoisted their hopes on the seething sea...

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: Only cause they lost their sail. Breca casually smacks Hondscioh hard in the arm. Hondscio mockingly plays great pain. Grins from some, but Thorkel undeterred.

dialogues.speaker: THORKEL
dialogues.text: The whale-road white as the tongues of trolls...

dialogues.speaker: BRECA
dialogues.text: (at Hondscioh / appreciative) Hear that? The tongues of trolls!

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: Arses, more like. This time both Beowulf and Breca raise their hands to str Hondscioh, who winces, duly preparing for the hits which this time - do not come.

dialogues.speaker: THORKEL
dialogues.text: The two fire-hearted friends fought on / Steel-shirts a goad to gruesome things / That crept up from their water-worlds --

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: Hold it there. (to Beowulf and Breca) You're in the boat? (off their looks) Things are going at you while you're still in the boat? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 20

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Beowulf shrugs, eyes Breca. Hondscioh follows his look.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Breca? You tell Thorkel that?

dialogues.speaker: BRECA
dialogues.text: Hondscioh, next time you're alone on open water, just remember not to drink it --

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: -+-again. The roars of LAUGHTER stir the child. Beowulf rises and carries the child to a bed of furs nearby.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: Any fish with any smell would sniff you two and heave. LAUGHTER.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Next time you tell a tale, Thorkel, try to sift the sheepshit out.

dialogues.speaker: THORKEL
dialogues.text: I sing what I'm told!

dialogues.speaker: HYGELAC
dialogues.text: The song might well be stronger than the bones it's built upon. Nods from the cluster. Thorkel is clearly miffed.

dialogues.speaker: THORKEL
dialogues.text: They bring me giants, I'll sing of giants. I can only work with the bones I'm given! Breca fires a look at Beowulf - who furtively indicates - nothing more happened, no thugs were killed.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: You want bones, we'll bring you bones. Troll-bones! A hint of seriousness slips over the group. Hygelac eyes Beowulf. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 21 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 21.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Hrothgar would cross the water for us. Looks shift about, drifting generally back to Hygelac who broods.

dialogues.speaker: HYGELAC
dialogues.text: I know he would. I've had no better neighbour-king. It's just that... by the sounds of this thing

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: +-.-it's never met a Geat. There is fierce pride in Beowulf's gaze, and proud nods f the others. Hygelac looks at Beowulf, torn.

dialogues.speaker: HYGELAC
dialogues.text: I won't keep you home to frighten fish. And, if you can... (indicates Hondscioh) ...find Hondscioh a wife. Our sheep can't take much more. LAUGHS all round - mostly from Breca. Hondscioh gamely shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LONGSHIP is being loaded, Beowulf watching over the process. He glances across the dock and sees... .-.-.a row of human HEADS, appearing to be sitting on a board... amongst them Hondscioh, Breca and Thorkel. One o the heads moves, starts speaking. Beowulf recoils a step, then relaxes, seeing the illusion ...the cluster of MEN standing by the boat, their bodies blocked by the dock. Beowulf strolls over to the group. Hondscioh is holding a harp in one hand, holding off a reaching Thorkel with the other.

dialogues.speaker: THORKEL
dialogues.text: Give it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 22 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 22.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: What - you plan to sing the thing to death? Breca snatches the harp from Hondscioh, hands it to Thork Hondscioh fires a dirty look at Breca, who smirks.

dialogues.speaker: THORKEL
dialogues.text: (to Beowulf re Hondscioh / warning) He puts one hand on my harp...

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: Beowulf, we're gonna need some extra shields. (off Beowulf's look / re Thorkel) For our ears.

dialogues.speaker: THORKEL
dialogues.text: (to Hondscioh) -..I warn you - you're a dead man. Hondscioh gives a mock-shudder. Breca and Beowulf trade a grin. Thorkel does not, placing his precious harp in a rabbit-skin bag. And the loading continues.

dialogues.speaker: DUSK 22
dialogues.text: Beowulf is slumped at the side of his LONGSHIP as it cuts through the water. TWELVE GEATS are with him [including Breca, Hondscioh and Thorkel], the sail doing all the wor One man is feeding the hearth fire on which meat is cooki

dialogues.speaker: THORKEL
dialogues.text: Say this thing makes meat of any man it finds.

dialogues.speaker: BRECA
dialogues.text: Danes say. Danes who ran. I've also known Danes who'll say they fought off Attila when he wandered North.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: (wry) Breca's right. Danes can't even swim after fish. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 23 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 23.

dialogues.speaker: BRECA
dialogues.text: Walrus, Hondscioh, and next one I catch, its tusk goes up your arse.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Worse things. Laughter from the group. And they sail on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glass-still channel of water, in which dozens of ICEBER stand... seeming to exude a blue-white light. PUSH IN / FIND: a small boat - an Irish CORACLE - driftin -.-in the aft of which a man in ragged monk's cloak - BRE [40s] - is sprawled, his ratty sail catching the bit of breeze, his hand draped over the rudder. He appears weak sick, his eyes those of a madman, fixed with suspicion on looming ice figures...

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: (slurred Irish mutter) -.-woe betide you beasts of ice... ogre, troll - I don't wary much... He raises one skinny arm like a weapon.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For I bring the burning sword of Christ! To cleave you thus... and thus... and thus! And he strikes out his arm in the symbol of the cross... before his energy leaves him and his arm drops.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Fine then. Hold your tongues... but dunna think I dunna know your methods and your manner! They say you lie more below than above and on a whim will swing your ice-blue asses up at God. Yesssss, well, do as you must... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 23 24 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 24.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He rises, clutching the mast, pointing accusingly at the icebergs.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: +..but hear this vow: I will melt you and drink you down and piss you out upon these shores... and -yes - you may freeze up and walk again... but only as a Christian thing! And he LAUGHS like a maniac, then loses his balance, fall hits his head on the edge of the coracle - in the process knocking himself out. And the coracle drifts, as before, now in quiet peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Brendan's weather-beaten - and unconscious - fa complete with a scabbed-over gouge in his forehead. A stone hits his cheek, he winces, his eyes fluttering bu staying closed. Brendan mutters incomprehensibly, twists sideways, resumi a fitful sleep. REVEAL: SELMA [30] standing on a pebble beach several fee from the run-aground coracle. Though her battered and sim clothes suggest poverty, there's strength and intelligenc apparent in her. Also wildness and a fierce beauty. She looks over Brendan... and his simple possessions. She sees a small sack, opens it, and brings out a handful silver crosses on chains. She considers them a moment, is putting them back, when...

dialogues.speaker: UNFERTH
dialogues.text: Selma! Selma turns to see... ..-Unferth - on the shoreline ridge, on HORSEBACK.

dialogues.speaker: UNFERTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Y'leave him as he lies! As Selma steps back from the coracle... ...Unferth gallops down beside them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 25.

dialogues.speaker: SELMA
dialogues.text: Whatever else, I'm no thief.

dialogues.speaker: UNFERTH
dialogues.text: I didn't say y'were. He might carry sickness. Y'bring it to land, we all could die. Selma studies Unferth a beat with vague contempt.

dialogues.speaker: SELMA
dialogues.text: By sickness, eh? Wouldn't that be welcome? (off his look) Already looking out for our people. You're not king yet, much as you dream it. Unferth lets it go. Looks over Brendan's garments.

dialogues.speaker: UNFERTH
dialogues.text: What sort of man...

dialogues.speaker: SELMA
dialogues.text: Celt. A priest.

dialogues.speaker: UNFERTH
dialogues.text: How can you tell?

dialogues.speaker: SELMA
dialogues.text: (sardonic) By knowing. Y'ever leave this land, you might know things too. (looks over Brendan) Needs mostly water... maybe fruit.

dialogues.speaker: UNFERTH
dialogues.text: Fruit? Selma considers the water, and her eyes faintly glaze.

dialogues.speaker: SELMA
dialogues.text: But there's others coming... a boatload of spears. Unferth glances up and down the shore with evident concer

dialogues.speaker: UNFERTH
dialogues.text: Slavs? No. We killed those yesterday. Selma shakes her head. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 25 26 27 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 26.

dialogues.speaker: SELMA
dialogues.text: (eryptic) These ones swim in blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE ON: the iceberg passage through which the longship glides. There is no conversation now, all the warriors moved inst by the eerieness of the light... .В»..some trying to draw warmth from the hearth fire. c/s: of Beowulf's hand dangling over the edge of the boat ON: his face as he closes his eyes. A small wave washes up across his arm.. .-.-and from the water a creature-like HAND reaches up, a fiercely snatches hold of his wrist. Beowulf twists around, rips his hand free... .В»--only to find it's been tangled in a rope from the sh ..-but, in the inky water below, a play of light... somet seeming to descend back down to the dark depths. Beowulf repositions his hand on the hilt of his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hrothgar is creakily putting on his mailshirt. Though onl months have passed since the troll's first attack, these months weigh on Hrothgar like many years. Too much grief- driven drink, too many sleepless nights, have brought him dull and watery gaze of a lost man. Wealhtheow, his wife, enters and looks troubled by Hrothg action.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: Who ever heard of a kingdom laid to waste by a stinking troll! (off her look) I can't game more men against this thing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 27.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hrothgar

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: Then don't. It's only in the night...

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: So then - I'm king - but only by day? sneers, spits on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck that. Wealhtheow, without missing a beat, snatches up a shirt a throws it to him. Hrothgar catches it, turns it in his ha She nods Hrothgar foot. Hrothgar comes to her with

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: One troll outside is plenty. to the spit: clean it up. throws the shirt down on his spit, rubs it with a

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: Maybe it needs the blood of a king. takes up a cup of beer, has a gulp, then Wealhtheow him and gently takes the cup away. He looks back at mixed emotions.

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: Don't let beer blur your wits.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: You called it "he."

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: Women seek a death for a loss. They get their blood-worth and settle. This has the blood-lust of a man.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: Which I have to quell... or I'm already dead. (off her look) If Odin sent this thing to bring my end... so be it. If not, then he'll steer my sword. (beat) My dear, I miss the stars. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 28 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 28.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Wealhtheow gently strokes his cheek. Her eyes glaze with tears, but her hands move down and help tie the straps of battle-gear. Hrothgar, meanwhile, takes up his battle-mask helmet - an stares into the hollow eye-sockets as if at a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hrothgar moves out from the torch-lit rock perimeter... a massive two-handed sword turning in his adrenalined grip. His eyes fight the darkness, and his fear.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: (shouts) Troll! I call you out! Nothing. Hrothgar takes several steps further.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Troll! A sudden rise of WIND, and Hrothgar twists about - as tho Grendel had taken wind-form, but the gust passes... silen resuming. WITH: A GUARD on the boulders watching Hrothgar in the mi distance facing out into the darkness. WITH: Hrothgar staring out, catching Grendel's scent on t air. Hrothgar's intensity returns, eyes scanning the periphery.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shouting) Meet me in the light if you have the guts. Or fight me now! You hairy creep! The guard shakes his head at Hrothgar's pathetic state

dialogues.speaker: GRENDEL
dialogues.text: (throaty mutter / Troll accent) Creep creep... The guard swings about, spear in hand, his gaze rising up fixing in terror... .В»..on Grendel, several yards along the boulder from him watching Hrothgar's performance. Grendel grins, shakes hi head... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 28 29 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 29.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The guard's mouth drops open, but his voice utterly fails him. Grendel's grin shifts to grimace... as an arm swings up. WITH: Hrothgar as he takes one or two more hesitant strid out into the darkness, sniffing the air, sensing somethin his intensity returning. PEBBLES skid to one side of him. Hrothgar wheels, ready t strike... but another silence follows. A shadow crosses Hrothgar. He wheels... В«--to meet a large shape descending through the air, whi tumbles in a limp heap, ending at Hrothgar's feet: the CO of the dead guard, his neck neatly snapped. WITH: Grendel, watching with grim amusement, from twenty away, one with the boulder he stands beside, as... ..-Hrothgar charges forward into the darkness, SCREAMING, swinging wildly and blindly with his sword... After several seconds of striking nothing, he stops - cat his breath - scanning around... but nothing suggests any shape. Finally there comes a CLICKING NOISE... and then - almost LAUGH . WITH: Hrothgar wheeling on the sound, making out the mass shape, which he charges toward... only to find, on arriva that the shape is the boulder... ..-.and Grendel is nowhere to be seen. CLOSE ON: Hrothgar staring helplessly out and then up to brilliant stars. A sad smile comes and tears fill his eye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wealhtheow urgently comes along the path... passing VILLA who are subdued, all looking toward... ..-Hrothgar who sits, hunched over, on a small rise, faci the wilds, the dead guard lying beside him. Wealhtheow hurries up to Hrothgar, looks him over with concern. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 30.

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: Are you wounded?

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: The thing wouldn't fight. It spared me... to witness this. 29 A shudder rolls through him and he lets out a gasp, eyein the corpse. Another jerking shudder... Wealhtheow glances back, sees the villagers watching, and whispering.

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Then get up off your arse... with your thanes in sight. This is no ground for a king.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: (caustic / dazed) Oh... you're wrong. For a king who's had his balls hauled up his guts... it's the ground. For all the broken-bone wretches I've flung to death --

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: And Valhalla. Hrothgar considers the terror in the face of the dead gua

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: I don't know. Is that the look of a man going happily up to the feast... or down to the worms?

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: You talk like a madman.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: No - just the Danish king of daylight!

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: Get up now... or do we bury you here?

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: Is that your wish? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 30 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 31.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Wealhtheow slaps him hard across the face - surprising herself.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (ironic) With your thanes in sight.

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: Whose wife would you have me be? Wealhtheow stares evenly at him. He sighs, shrugs. Wealhtheow turns and strides back up into the enclosure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Selma is picking berries. The sound of a HORSE approachin She turns to find... ...Wealhtheow there. Wealhtheow dismounts, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: SELMA
dialogues.text: (nodding to a spot) Watch yourself.

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: You think I've lost feel for the ground.

dialogues.speaker: SELMA
dialogues.text: There's brambles there... bog there. Last thing I need's a dead queen on my hands.

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: You've had worse and I've been far far less - dead or otherwise. Wealhtheow sits down on a rock, while Selma keeps picking long silence.

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Selma, should I fear for my husband?

dialogues.speaker: SELMA
dialogues.text: If you've got nothing better to do.

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: Sweet, don't play the bitch with me. I don't ask much and I don't ask often. No one dares dirty your name around me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 31 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 32.

dialogues.speaker: SELMA
dialogues.text: (ironic) Nor yours around me. They trade the hint of a smile.

dialogues.speaker: SELMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) Hrothgar dies happy... in his sleep.

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: That's a lift.

dialogues.speaker: SELMA
dialogues.text: Take them where we can, eh. Wealhtheow smiles, nods. A silence.

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: I could find a place for you inside.

dialogues.speaker: SELMA
dialogues.text: We chose our beds a long time back. The women share a look. Wealhtheow nods. Selma continues with her berries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A funeral pyre burns with the corpse of the guard. ON: Hrothgar sitting on a rock a short distance off, polishing his sword with a cloth...

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: That's one shiny sword. Hrothgar turns to find... .--Brendan shuffling toward him. He's a bit of a sight: i his dark and ratty monk's wool cassock, hollowed eye sock and fierce - almost unblinking - gaze, plus a wonky and unpredictable gait.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm told you're the Danes' king. (off Hrothgar's stare) Northumbria wishes you well. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 33

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: Celt. You're a ways away.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: I am... but safe with the sword of Christ. Father Brendan. Brendan bows slightly, his large crucifix swinging forwar

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: I see a man, I see a staff... (xe the crucifix) I see a weapon for killing toads. (off Brendan's shrug) Christ, eh? I've heard of him. He ever have much luck with trolls?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: I'm under the thought they never crossed paths. (off Hrothgar's dismissive look) But if you're willing to bow before Christ, you shall feel the blessing of his great strength.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: My gods don't ask me to bow.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Nor should they dare... if they won't protect you. This stings Hrothgar. His hand squeezes the hilt of his sword, but he resists striking Brendan. Brendan remains unperturbed. He eyes the pyre... as the guard is lifted upon it. A gua begins to blow on a horn - calling the villagers to the burning.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To face God's foes is an honour. I've come to drive this evil out.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: With your stick?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: With the fire of Heaven! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 32 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 34.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: If your heaven's on fire, y'better look to that. Brendan gets a furious look, and starts to pace before Hrothgar. Hrothgar, in spite of himself, is a bit impress by Brendan's intensity.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Leave me on a dish for the troll, then! Leave me and, if I don't see man's dawn, I shall see God's! I shall see God's! Brendan gazes fiercely at Hrothgar a moment, his eyes bli repeatedly, then he collapses on the ground. Unferth strides up, checks Brendan, his breathing, his ey

dialogues.speaker: UNFERTH
dialogues.text: He's asleep. All Hrothgar can manage is a sigh, a shake of the head at grim farce his life has become.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beowulf's longship edges into the shallows of a black beach... stone promontories rising high on either side. He and half his men jump down into the water, and - guide ropes in hand - haul the boat up upon the stones. As the men in the boat begin passing over their battle-ge to those in the water... В«--they turn to the sound of a NEIGHING HORSE... .---and see ERIK [a coast-guard] come galloping down thro break in the rock, and pull up in the stones... just out spear distance.

dialogues.speaker: ERIK
dialogues.text: Hold there!

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: As you wish. Is this land Dane?

dialogues.speaker: ERIK
dialogues.text: It is... and you're not. So unless, you're ripe for a shower of arrows, you'll tell who you are. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 33 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 35.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hondscioh gives a great amused laugh at Erik's threat. Er unamused, lifts from his hip a horn.

dialogues.speaker: ERIK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Two blows of this and fifty men will be on these cliffs before you've strapped your ring-shirts.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: Fifty birds maybe.

dialogues.speaker: ERIK
dialogues.text: (a threat) Is that then your word?

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: I'm Beowulf -- The name registers sharply with Erik.

dialogues.speaker: ERIK
dialogues.text: Beowulf the Geat.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: (nods) We come as friends to Hrothgar. Erik looks over their equipment, and over Beowulf - tryin mask his awe.

dialogues.speaker: ERIK
dialogues.text: We welcome friends. Bring what you need. I'1l have men look to your ship. Erik blows ONCE on his HORN... the powerful and eerie sou echoing off the cliffs.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: One blow is good news?

dialogues.speaker: ERIK
dialogues.text: One blow is good. Hondscioh winks good-naturedly. Erik glances at Beowulf w shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beowulf's troop, loaded with their weaponry - shields, swords, axes, spears - walk across the even ground, led b Erik with his horse. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 34 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 36.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Moss-ridden rock rises on either side, boulders and irreg ridges suggesting menacing shapes... frozen for now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Erik and the Geats come up over a rise, and into sight of... В«-+-the Danish village. Erik rides up ahead to... .В»..a GUARD at the break in the rocks who, after a momen Erik, waves them in. The Geats continue forward, scanning... ...VILLAGERS clustered around a couple funeral pyres. The villagers stare back - listless, forlorn, dead-eyed - at Geats.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: (low to the other Geats) By Thor... they've got the spark of cows.

dialogues.speaker: BRECA
dialogues.text: How bout that one. Beowulf and Hondscioh follow Breca's gaze... -..to Selma, coming from the opposite direction, carrying baskets. She's a jolt of vigor and beauty, especially set against the dregs through which she moves. Beowulf finds her studying him with interest; he edges up Erik.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Who's the one with the baskets?

dialogues.speaker: ERIK
dialogues.text: Selma. A witch. The happy would keep a boat-length from her.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: (lascivious) Happiness isn't everything.

dialogues.speaker: ERIK
dialogues.text: She sees people's deaths. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 35 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 37.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: (wry disappointment) Wouldn't you know. And they continue on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geats come up to the great hall - a magnificent wood stone structure, three stories high. Below the eaves is h the great pair of buck's antlers, and around these are or wood carvings. The Geats are obviously impressed.

dialogues.speaker: BRECA
dialogues.text: That's one beer-hall, eh Hondscioh? Before Hondscioh can respond...

dialogues.speaker: ERIK
dialogues.text: If you like to drink with ghosts. As the Geats consider this, a commotion rises behind them They turn to see... ---.a cluster of men striding toward them, the commotion coming from the older man at the center who is GROWLING impatience, Unferth at his side, muttering explanations. As they near, Beowulf recognizes the old man as... .--Hrothgar, who is half-drunk and just roused from sleep Hrothgar, seeing Beowulf, strides clear of his own retinu Beowulf struggles to mask his surprise at the king's wret appearance.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: By the gods! My little Beowulf! (derisive nod to his retinue) No one tells me anything. He comes up to Beowulf and gives him a great hug... then holds him at a short distance, looking him over, grinning

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I somehow think of you as smaller.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: I was eight when I left. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 36 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 38.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: You've grown! Smiles all around.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. We didn't mean to wake you.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: Wake me?! I'm a grief-crippled king half-drunk in the middle of the afternoon! What's to wake? (beat / eyes welling) By the gods it's good to see you! (beat) Perhaps Odin too has woken from his slumber. WIDE ON: the group... Hrothgar's guards to one side... th impressive band of Geats opposite... all joining in SMILE As Hrothgar leads them into the hall, the Geats pass... ..-Brendan who stands to one side, beatific smile on his face, apple in hand. He locks gazes with Hondscioh as the pass, and blesses the group with the sign of the cross. Hondscioh forces an awkward smile, nods, continues past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: a human's dried-out HEAD on a cliff-edge facing inland. Several similar-size rocks sit in close proximity The head is almost down to bone, with some skin and a rat scalp of hair... Another rock rolls up toward the head, but comes to rest before it reaches it. Silence... then another rock tumbles up toward the head, that much closer, but stops as well. A snarling EXPLETIVE in Troll-tongue:

dialogues.speaker: GRENDEL
dialogues.text: Yahhhg! REVEAL: Grendel, the rock-thrower, as he takes his stance once more... MUTTERS reassurance to himself... then heave third rock toward the head. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 37 38 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 39.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: This rock crashes into the head, knocking it over the cli

dialogues.speaker: GRENDEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (high-pitched giddy yelp) Heeeee! He struts about, chest swelling... then settles his gaze and sigh - on the sunset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mead hall glows with a profusion of TORCHES - both in and out - stunning against the twilight, the great warm h it was meant to be. LAUGHTER and MUSIC from within...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The benches are full of warriors and earls, one side the troop, on the other the Danes... On the Danes' side, there are considerably more women tha men, the women talking between themselves, flirtatiously eyeing the revved-up Geats. ON: Breca scanning several women, his mouth falling open nerve-stunned lust. Hondscioh, beside him, reaches over a nudges his mouth closed. Between the two groups the fire-pits burn. LAUGHTER and talk compete with a MUSICIAN playing a HARP, SECOND with a bone FLUTE, a THIRD playing a BODHRAN. Hrothgar sits at one end of the room, Beowulf nearest him There's abundant food and jugs of beer being delivered to warriors by teenaged ATTENDANTS. Wealhtheow, passing behind Beowulf, leans in to him, indicates the numerous women.

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: If a Geat were seeking a wife, this room would hold better hope than most.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: So many -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 40.

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: Widows. (off Beowulf's look) Widows far too early. Beowulf nods, glances across the group and his gaze meets ...Unferth, who is fixed on him, with an ugly look. Unfer takes a long draught from his drink, clearly well on the to drunk. Wealhtheow reluctantly pours beer from a jug into the dru Hrothgar's cup. With some effort he stands.

dialogues.speaker: AESCHERE
dialogues.text: Ho! And the room goes silent. Hrothgar looks about, eyes watering. He smiles, but as quickly gets overwhelmed with emotion. Catches a huge breath. The grief and fear and hopelessness wash over his face. He clears his throat, but nothing follows. He scans the group, shrugs apologetically, LAUGHS - but i nothing the others can join in on. Wealhtheow gently puts a hand on his shoulder, whispers something in his ear. He nods and lowers himself back to seat. Wealhtheow turns to the assembly.

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: With my king I welcome you all. Too many days we've drunk to forget the night, and what it brings. But today we drink to what the day's brought - thirteen swords against our curse. Thirteen men to swell our weary... (soft, suggestive) ++-walls. Wealhtheow turns to Beowulf and fills his cup.

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll never forget this gift. And she moves along the row of Geats pouring into each cu (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 41

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Beowulf rises, and he too finds himself a bit emotional. gaze drifts over the group as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: I'll say this once: this is no gift, coming here is the least I can do. Danes, you sheltered me as a child. Some of you here are old enough to remember. To the rest I say only I come as a brother. (beat) These others with me made their own minds. We mean to bring an end to this fiend --

dialogues.speaker: UNFERTH
dialogues.text: (loud mutter) As others vowed...

dialogues.speaker: WEALHTHEOW
dialogues.text: uUnferth!

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: By your will, dear queen... we're wiser in knowing the hearts of those who've tangled with the thing. A brief silence through which Unferth and Beowulf lock ga

dialogues.speaker: AESCHERE
dialogues.text: (sharp / eyeing Unferth) Those are dead.

dialogues.speaker: UNFERTH
dialogues.text: I don't brag of wrestling with it, nor of being able to kill it. (beat) The troll broke down these doors with twenty Danish warriors sleeping inside. What gives thirteen Geats better hope?

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: We won't be sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: UNFERTH
dialogues.text: No - more likely bragging of your fights with cod-fish. A coldness sweeps through the room, the Geats on edge. Aeschere rises, livid, glaring at Unferth. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 39 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 42.

dialogues.speaker: AESCHERE
dialogues.text: If you don't know what this man has done, you'll shut your hole or have it shut for you. If you do know, then so much the worse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hrothgar glances over, blinking up out of his fog.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: (to Unferth) So, friend - unscathed amidst all this death - should we guess you've steered your way clear of bragging? Unferth gets a wild look, rises from his seat, hand to hi sword-hilt. But just as suddenly Hrothgar has risen, this time with fury.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: Unferth! Sit or see your guts ina * dish. Unferth looks suddenly puzzled, the beer fogging his head Finally he sits. Hrothgar eyes the Geats, struggling for focus.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Forgive us forgetting the ways of kin. Beowulf, if you do as you vow, there's nothing you can wish for that won't be yours - if I have any weight in it. (beat) Now, before the dark must sharpen us again, songs and beer! As an attendant reaches to pour into Hrothgar's cup, he covers it with his hand, shakes his head. The musicians begin again, and the attendants bring more beer... conversations rising up all around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The far-off sound of LAUGHTER from the hall drifts over t field. And a dark silhouette rises in the foreground: Grendel, slowing at the sound. He listens with puzzlement - which shifts to irritation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 40 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 43.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He shakes his head categorically...

dialogues.speaker: GRENDEL
dialogues.text: (firm mutter) Na-na-na-na... na-na-na-na... .В»..and he lopes off toward the distant lights, his stri lengthening, arms swinging, landscape streaming under his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Geat warriors below and inside set up their equipm preparing for an attack - with a drunken Unferth watching them suspiciously... ..-Beowulf and Hrothgar stand on the open balcony, lookin out on the falling dark. Hrothgar's mood is grim... in sp of the RAUCOUS men below... but he's more clear-headed.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: Since it began we've had Saxons, Swedes... even Slavs... coming to see how weak we were. Beowulf studies Hrothgar a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know. I look like walrus shit. Comes of fighting things you can't. Hrothgar manages a weak smile. Beowulf clasps Hrothgar's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: All bad dreams end. We'll see you in the morning for herring and egg.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: Herring and egg. As Beowulf turns toward the battlement... a desperate loo crosses Hrothgar's face, struggling with the things he ca say.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: If there's anything you need to tell me about it... now would be the time. Hrothgar fights a shudder. Beowulf again takes hold of hi shoulder, steadies him. Hrothgar clenches Beowulf's hand. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 40A
dialogues.text: 41 42 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 44.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: I'll stay here amongst you. Beowulf shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: We'll bring you the head. Throw it in with the herring and egg. They trade smiles. Hrothgar studies Beowulf, sees his ste resolve. For the first time in ages Hrothgar risks hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN OVER: the thirteen Geats, some lying on mats on the floor, some on benches, one or two slumped back in sittin position against the walls, all with weapons at the ready All alert and waiting... -+-all except Unferth, who lies back, snoring loudly. Beowulf sits at the foot of the empty throne, staring int the embers of the fire-pit, his great sword in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brendan is kneeling at the bottom of a slope leading up t the mead hall. He is facing the wilds, and quietly PRAYIN in LATIN. The huge shape of Grendel edges into the light, headed on line from the rocks - through Brendan - to the hall. Brendan, sniffing the air, visibly tenses but continues i prayer, eyes closed. Grendel - still yards away - slows to a stop, and takes h own long sniff of Brendan. Clearly it puzzles him: a man- smell he's not met before. As Brendan's prayer increases in breathiness... .--Grendel curves off and around him, then onward up to t hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ember POPS... and it's followed immediately by the CRE of straining timber... Beowulf's gaze swings to the doors...  43 44 45 46 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grendel leans toward the doors, sniffing - and even more puzzled by the smells from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From outside the sound of Grendel's SNIFFING... The warriors swing up from their beds, adrenaline of batt rushing in - but they're cautious to not betray their readiness - all eyes are open, all mouths closed. Some men remain squatting; others stand, weapons drawn in preparation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Grendel holding his forearm horizontally agains the door... seeming to test its strength. Grendel's head then slumps forward, forehead resting agai the arm. Grendel closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There then comes a longer CREAK and a gentle - yet enormo pressure on the bolted doors from outside... a great SIGH Beowulf, sword at the ready, edges to the door... Hondsci and Breca at his side... There's a silence... the warriors' apprehension building. ...then a prolonged TRICKLE sound... Beowulf looks down, and immediately jerks back a step, avoiding... CLOSE ON: a liquid - Grendel's urine - pooling under the door. Beowulf gives his men a look; they all move forward as Beowulf angrily throws off the locking timber, and swings open the door, swings back his blade... ...to find only darkness, and the staggering stench of th troll's piss-mark.  47 48 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON: Brendan, eyes closed, still praying... as a huge SHAD thrown by the mead hall torches - passes over him... ...a THROATY SNICKER from the passerby, and then he is go Brendan lets out a sigh, but does not open his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON: BLACKSMITHS turning glowing pokers against the staine wood of the great doors... burning off Grendel's urine. Beowulf, Hondscioh and Hrothgar, amongst others, watch fr one side. Hrothgar is puzzled but relieved.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: Worse things than a bloodless dawn.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: He let us rest... the worse for him.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: He ever leave men alive in the hall?

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: Since it began... Hrothgar shakes his head. The three men trade a look. Beowulf's drifting gaze finds .--.-Brendan, a short distance off, sitting on a rock - a indiscernible among the boulders surrounding him. He's chewing on an apple, studying the others. Beowulf strides down to him, Hondscioh and Hrothgar following.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Priest, where did you spend the night? Brendan considers him a moment, then nods to the spot whe he'd been praying.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You didn't move at all through the night? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 47

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: (considers, shrugs) Up once to piss, but... Beowulf gives a dubious look.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (wry, rhetorical) Why was such a daft wretch spared? (beat / fervent) Demon's wise enough to know a messenger of God! To touch my cloak's to bring God's very fire and storm upon its head.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: That's not what he asked. Brendan stares back at Hondscioh a beat, then - ignoring turns to Hrothgar.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Wise king, you must know the name of Clovis.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: The Frank.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: (faintly condescending) The Frank, yes. Yes, the Frank. (beat / intense) The Christian sword over land ten times what the Danes hold dear!

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: He's dead.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Did I say he was a god? (beat) He's dead, yes, ten years now -- but not before he saw God's grace: the Visigoths of Aquitaine, the Romans under Syagrius, Burgundians, Alamans all fell before him! And all because he had God's ear! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 Beowulf

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 48.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: If I recall, he also had a thousand swords, neighbours gone soft on wine and pig, no ice on his rivers -

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: And no fucking trolls.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: And no trolls.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: My skinny hand can only bless. But trust me - this thing shall meet its end in striking me... or those of mine. Brendan shuffles off. The three share a look.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Madness has its wonders.

dialogues.speaker: UNFERTH
dialogues.text: (throaty) The Celt sat straight in the path of the thing... and was not touched. The three turn to see a haggard, hungover Unferth approac Hondscioh

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: (mutter) The dead do walk.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: (to Hrothgar) The Celt held no sword. Perhaps the thing hates weapons.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: But your men were armed. fixes on Unferth and his sword.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: Others here in arms have been spared. Unferth gives him a threatening look. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 49

dialogues.speaker: UNFERTH
dialogues.text: I've waited for Odin to bring me my death. He hasn't.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: (wry) In his wisdom? Unferth trembles with indignation, sensing insult, but there's little to take hold of. He turns and strides away

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: There walks one of my toughest fighters. He still is with men... but the troll stole his spine. Beowulf broods a beat.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Do you know where the thing makes its home?

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: We followed a blood-trail once, took us to the foot of cliffs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the steam/mist burning off the water... -.. Erik leads Beowulf and the Geats - on horseback - dow the black sand beach, DOGS running ahead... В«--to a wall of daunting cliff, at the bottom of which t dogs sniff and howl. Beowulf, Hondscioh and Breca consider the challenging cli

dialogues.speaker: ERIK
dialogues.text: This is where the blood trails led.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: Not much known to daylight climbs up that.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Which is why he gets his rest. Beowulf starts up through the rocks... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 50 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 50.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: I tell you, this troll must be one tough prick... (off Breca's look / wry) Do this climb every night after supper? And the others proceed to follow Beowulf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geat troop is edging up the rocky bluff, but warily, warriors struggling to gauge the shadows which shift with shifting mist. THORFINN [20s], wiry and vigorous, leads the way now... .--with Beowulf and Hondscioh just a bit back of him. Hondscioh eyes Erik.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: You want to blow your horn now, I wouldn't mind those fifty bows you bragged of.

dialogues.speaker: ERIK
dialogues.text: I could bring the bows. But the men are gone. Beowulf gives Hondscioh a look... but his gaze then fixes on... .--Thorfinn who, stepping up, takes hold of a jutting hun driftwood for support...

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: This is too high up for driftwood. (warning) Thorfinn! As Thorfinn stops and turns, Beowulf urgently scans aroun There comes the SOUND of shifting rock just above Thorfin The piece of wood comes free in his hand, he loses his footing, and tumbles back... From a ridge just above him there swings down a great rac curved white spikes... Thorfinn scrambles to the side, just missing impalement.. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 51 52 53 54 55 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 51.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ..-before the rack lodges in the rocks on either side. * Beowulf and Hondscioh - swords drawn - edge up to the * whalebone barrier. They scan through the steadily increasing FOG.

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: vee tty) ; Little high up for a whale's ribs? They each take hold of a side of the contraption, but it not budge.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: This is sharpened bone...

dialogues.speaker: HONDSCIOH
dialogues.text: ...and rigged to swing. * (to Erik) What are we fighting here?

dialogues.speaker: ERIK
dialogues.text: A thing beyond our ken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Geats stride along a cleft between a sea of glacial boulders. They are moving quickly - though warily - but there is more ferocity than fear in their eyes. The rocky outcrops suggest figures looming, between the m and mist and stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON: brawny hands seeking grip in the top of a boulder. Th do - and with a GRUNT of effort.. * ..-Beowulf pulls himself up into view. * His expression - that of the hunter on the scent of prey loses its fierceness, shifting abruptly to that of a man at sea... * As Hondscioh and Breca come up on either side of him... * (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 55 56 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 52.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ...the three gaze out over... * -..a massive glacial plain rising up for several miles. *

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: We're out of our world. The three consider the magnificent - if eerie - rippled i on either side of which rise only boulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON: GRIMUR, a misfit Dane, standing in the river down fro the waterfall, being baptized by Brendan HOWLING out * indecipherable Latin. * ON: Hrothgar sitting on a rock overlooking a waterfall, a facing down to the pool below the falls, his eyes watery, face wet. Some yards back of him stands his HORSE. * The Geat troop appear on the ridge, Beowulf at the head. Beowulf nears and... ..-Hrothgar - startled by the approach - wheels about, sw in hand. Orients himself. Wipes the mist/tears from his face. Forces an awkward smile...

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: I was off in a dream.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Wish I could bring a better one. Hrothgar scans their ranks, sees all intact. *

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This thing's smart as a man. *

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: Were it less, it'd hang on my wall.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Have you ever tried to trap it?

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: Ten men waited one night. Ready. With nets, swords, spears. It went through them like salmon.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Yet it didn't try us. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 56 Beowulf & Grendel - 10th dr. - Berzins - July 12/04 - 53.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: (weary smile) Perhaps you smell off. Beowulf's gaze drifts to the water below the falls. ANGLE DOWN ON: curious VILLAGERS scattered along the riverbank, also watching... ...-Brendan, in his cloak, standing with Unferth now who naked to the waist, in the middle of the swirling stream. Brendan, SCREAMING his LATIN against the roar of the fall takes up a handful of water, and splashes Unferth in the of the cross. Hrothgar and Beowulf consider the ritual.

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Baptism they call it. Unferth feels he's fallen from the gaze of our gods.

dialogues.speaker: BEOWULF
dialogues.text: Did Unferth's king give him this freedom? (off Hrothgar's shrug) You don't fear he has an eye on your throne?

dialogues.speaker: HROTHGAR
dialogues.text: I know he does. My sons are dead.
